A 90% accuracy rate in trading positions, even with varying correlations and beta weightings, is considered good. Beta is a fundamental tool for managing systemic risk by comparing underlyings to a benchmark like SPY.

We exclusively use SPY as our benchmark for trading. This approach, known as the "Apples to Apples" of the trading business, was pioneered by us 25 years ago. We introduced the concept of beta-weighting portfolios for retail investors, which has since been adopted by other firms. You can access this tool on Thinkorswim.

Interactive Brokers may have changed the industry for active traders using beta weighted portfolios. There are two definitions for beta of an underlying, with formulas provided for those interested in the specifics.

definitions used on the platform. Beta is the measure of how much to expect a stock to move given a $1 move in the underlying asset. We use 15 years of data for stocks such as SPY, IWM, TLT, Q's, Amazon, Google, and Tesla to compute the beta-weighted Deltas. This helps determine the reliability of this expectation in reality.

betas and beta weighted Deltas were calculated based on the previous 5 years of returns. The relationship between the underlying and the S&P was analyzed by contrasting realized daily moves against those predicted by Beta and the S&P moves via correlation. The average absolute error as a percent of the daily move and its root mean error were also considered.

We reported on the correlation between each underlying and the Spy over the whole data set. The correlation with Spy is 0.88 when using IWM and 0.93 when using Q's over 15 years. TLT would be the inverse correlation.
TLT has an inverse correlation of 0.32 with predicted and realized moves. The average error as a percentage of the average move is 7.7% in IWM, 12.2% in TLT, and 4.2% in QQQ.

In TLT, the error is 7.7 and in Q's it is 4.2, with stock indices being closer to 5%. The beta values are around 95% accurate for big outlier moves, with slightly higher errors in IWM and Q's, averaging around 8%.
The average ERA is low now. Amazon, Google, and Tesla have a low correlation to the S&P. Lower correlation results in higher error count in trading.

predicted moves are pretty accurate overall. The average error is slightly higher than the index values of Amazon (8.4), Google (2), and Tesla (9.3). Outlier moves are slightly higher but still under 10%. This shows that our platform's beta-weighted deltas and predicted moves are generally accurate.
analyze our portfolio's risk exposure. It's impressive that you're able to manage 70-80 positions and keep the error below 10%. That level of accuracy is hard to beat.

Weighted Deltas provide a way to assess total systemic risk in a portfolio based on expected gains or losses from a $1 market move. The value of this expectation is influenced by the strength of each underlying market correlation. Less correlated assets allow for more room for error. Realized price changes generally aligned with Beta predictions within a 10% margin, with Q showing closer alignment. Assets with lower correlations had higher price discrepancies.

Correlations between underlyings had higher root mean square errors, indicating they closely followed beta-weighted delta predictions. Low correlation underlyings are important for increasing occurrences, but their small beta-weighted deltas mean their prices are not necessarily stable. It can be difficult to predict their moves.
This study is effective at predicting typical stock movements but not outliers. It is important to consider its findings.
